title.text: Polarity sensitivity and evaluation order in type-logical grammar

abstractContent.text: We present a novel, type-logical analysis of polarity sensitivity: how negative polarity items (like any and ever) or positive ones (like some) are licensed or prohibited.
It takes not just scopal relations but also linear order into account , using the programming-language notions of delimited continuations and evaluation order, respectively.
It thus achieves greater empirical coverage than previous proposals.

introductionContent.text: Polarity sensitivity has been a popular linguistic phenomenon to analyze in the categorial, lexical-functional), and type-logical) approaches to grammar.

The multitude of these analyses is in part due to the more explicit emphasis that these traditions place on the syntax-semantics interface-be it in the form of Montague-style semantic rules, the CurryHoward isomorphism, or linear logic as glue-and the fact that polarity sensitivity is a phenomenon that spans syntax and semantics.
On one hand, which polarity items are licensed or prohibited in a given linguistic environment depends, by and large, on semantic properties of that environment.
For example, to a first approximation, negative polarity items can occur only in downward-entailing contexts, such asunder the scope of a monotonically decreasing quantifier.

The syntactic relations allowed between licensor and licensee for polarity sensitivity purposes are similar to those allowed between antecedent and pronoun for variable binding purposes.

To take one example, just as an antecedent's ability to bind a (c-commanded) pronoun percolates up to a containing phrase (such as in, what Büring (2001) calls "binding out of DP"), a licensor's ability to license a (c-commanded) polarity item percolates up to a containing phrase (such as in).

Moreover, just as a bindee can precede a binder in a sentence when the bindee sits in a clause that excludes the binder (as in; see Williams, 1997, §2.1), a licensee can precede a licensor in a sentence when the licensee sits in a clause that excludes the licensor (as in; see Ladusaw, 1979, page 112).
